title: Respiratory Infections

Topic summary contributed by volunteer(s): John A respiratory infection occurs when respiratory epithelium lining the upper and/or lower tract are overcome by a virus, bacteria, or fungus. Upper respiratory infection is usually not serious, like the [common "cold"](https://nutritionfacts.org/topics/common-cold) or sinus infection. On the other hand, lower respiratory tract infection may be serious or even life threatening, such as [pneumonia](https://nutritionfacts.org/topics/pneumonia/) where pus fills the air sacs. Things that may increase the risk of respiratory infection are strenuous [exercise](https://nutritionfacts.org/topics/exercise), [asthma](https://nutritionfacts.org/topics/asthma), [allergies](https://nutritionfacts.org/topics/allergies), and [immune suppression](https://nutritionfacts.org/topics/immune-function) (i.e., from cancer, chemotherapy, or other conditions or medications). Recent studies have strongly suggested that [children](https://nutritionfacts.org/topics/children) with asthma have fewer flare-ups and steroid usage when they go on a [plant-based](https://nutritionfacts.org/topics/plant-based-diets) diet rich in [fruits](https://nutritionfacts.org/topics/fruit), [vegetables](https://nutritionfacts.org/topics/vegetables), and grains, and eliminate animal products ( [meat](https://nutritionfacts.org/topics/meat), fish, dairy, [eggs](https://nutritionfacts.org/topics/eggs)). There are things we can do to protect ourselves from respiratory infection, such as hand washing and avoiding others' coughing and sneezing fits. Even [gargling](https://nutritionfacts.org/topics/gargling/) helps rinse away potential invading organisms. Other preventative measures are moderate exercise, which may strengthen the respiratory epithelium, and controlling asthma and allergies.
